title: 105_hr4865
content: The "Checkoff for Charity Act of 1998" is also known as the "Designation of Overpayments and Contributions for Charity" under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It allows for the designation of overpayments and contributions for charity. Individual taxpayers can designate a portion of their overpayment of tax and any cash contribution on their tax return to be paid to an eligible organization or for a specific use under the Checkoff for Charity Act of 1998. This designation must be made at the time of filing the tax return and in the manner prescribed by the Secretary. Individual taxpayers can designate a portion of their overpayment of tax on their tax return to be paid to an eligible organization. The designation must be made at the time of filing the return. Refunds for overpayments are treated as being refunded to the taxpayer as of the last date prescribed for filing the return. Part IX. Designation of overpayments and contributions for charity. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998. SEC. 102. CHECKOFF FOR CHARITIES TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section: "SEC. 9511. CHECKOFF FOR CHARITIES TRUST FUND." The Checkoff for Charities Trust Fund is established in the Treasury, funded by appropriations or designated amounts. The Secretary pays the Checkoff for Charities Commission from the Trust Fund quarterly, minus administrative expenses. The Checkoff for Charities Trust Fund pays administrative expenses of the Secretary, available as provided in the Checkoff for Charity Act of 1998. Amounts in the Fund cover expenses directly allocable to modifying tax forms, carrying out related chapters, and processing received amounts. The Checkoff for Charity Commission is established in the Department of Commerce, with duties outlined for the Commission. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The Checkoff for Charity Commission, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, arranges for voluntary charitable agencies to solicit contributions through tax returns. Contributions are limited to specified organizations and must be paid within 90 days. The Checkoff for Charity Commission arranges for voluntary charitable agencies to solicit contributions through tax returns. Contributions must be paid to the designated organization within 90 days. If contributions are not designated for a specific organization, the Commission may retain one percent for administrative purposes and distribute the rest to eligible organizations based on criteria. The Commission selects organizations based on criteria from Executive Order 12353, amended by Executive Order 12404. SEC. 203. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed by the President, representing diverse groups in the U.S. They must not be affiliated with organizations funded by the Act, and political party appointments are limited. Members serve six-year terms, with exceptions for initial appointees. Appointments can bypass certain executive schedule limitations. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President for six-year terms. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members serve without pay, except for full-time federal employees. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President for six-year terms. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members serve without pay, except for full-time federal employees. Members of the Commission who are full-time officers or employees of the United States may not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits by reason of their service on the Commission. Each member shall receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence. Eight members constitute a quorum, but a lesser number may hold hearings. The Chairman and Vice Chairman are designated by the President at the time of appointment, with the Chairman serving a three-year term. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairman or a majority of its members. SEC. 204. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who will be paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff as needed, following civil service laws for appointments and pay rates. The Director of the Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is granted powers under Section 205. The Commission, under Section 205, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and obtain official data from government departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises for aiding its work. Money and proceeds received shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement. The Commission can use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Additionally, the Commission has subpoena power. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in a court order to appear before the Commission. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in a court order to appear before the Commission in the district where the person is found, resides, or transacts business. Subpoenas must be served according to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, and all court process can be served in the judicial district where the person resides or can be found. Immunity is granted to individuals except in specific circumstances. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence. Individuals can claim the privilege against self-incrimination, and immunity is granted except for perjury. The Commission may contract with government and private agencies for property and services. The Commission is required to submit an annual report detailing its activities to the Secretary of Commerce and Congress by December 31 each year. Additionally, there is authorization for appropriations for startup costs for the Commission for the first two fiscal years after the enactment of the Act.
